Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Determining Pathways of Diagenetic Sulfurization of Organic Matter Using Compound-Specific Sulfur Isotopic Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sulfur is an essential element for all living organisms because it plays a critical role in transferring biochemical energy, enzymatic reactions, and protein synthesis. Thus, the biological and geological chemistry of sulfur is of widespread interest in the Earth science community. Organic sulfur deposited in sedimentary environments is of particular interest due to its impact on petroleum formation and refining and its relationship to microbial sedimentary processes, organic carbon accumulation and the overall interpretation of environmental records. This sedimentary organic matter retains the organic and inorganic history of sulfur initially incorporated into organic tissue (primary) or added during chemical reactions occurring in the sediments (secondary). Despite the importance, little is known about organic sulfur in the natural environment in part because there are a wide variety of organic sulfur compounds and a number of different ways these compounds form. In addition, these compounds can be altered after they are deposited in the sediments. The investigators will use the stable isotope composition of organic sulfur to gain insights into these processes and sources of organic sulfur. Recent technological advances have greatly improved the ability to measure sulfur isotope compositions of individual organic sulfur compounds possible with high precision and at natural abundance. This project will use compound-specific sulfur isotope analysis to study the reaction pathways that form organic sulfur in two anoxic (oxygen free) lakes. The sulfur isotope signature of these compounds will be used to infer reaction pathways to increase understanding of the reactions between sulfur and organic matter that occur in sediments. These new advancements in sulfur isotope analysis have tremendous potential for understanding past changes in elemental cycling, metabolic and ecologic changes, as well as changes in past climatic and environmental conditions.

Graduate education will be one broader impact of this project, and we will foster this through extensive collaboration and training in the state of the art sulfur isotope analysis. A second important impact of this project will be to develop educational modules about hypoxic (low oxygen) conditions common to northeast Indiana lakes, and Lake Erie, Pennsylvania, in collaboration with the IUPUI Center for Earth and Environmental Sciences (CEES) Discovering the Science of the Environment (DSE) program. DSE is a public outreach program focused on formal and informal delivery of STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) education to fourth through ninth grade students. We will translate knowledge learned from studying sulfur cycling in anoxic lakes into material for teaching modules that inform students about the environmental hazards of human-induced hypoxia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the ways in which organic compounds that contain sulfur are preserved in sediments. Known as organic sulfur, these compounds have important implications for petroleum formation and refining. They also retain unique information about the microbial reactions and the environmental setting in which they were formed. Although important, little is known about the ways these compounds form or about the rates of their formation. We used the stable isotope composition of organic sulfur to gain insights into the reactions that form them.

By sampling oxygen deficient lakes that contain high concentrations of sulfur in the water and the sediment, we were able to characterize the relative abundances of mineral sulfides, such as pyrite, and organic sulfur. The sampling locations included Mahoney Lake in British Columbia and Green Lake in New York. Both lakes have been the focus of previous scientific research from which to draw critical background information for the project. Another lake, Lime Blue, in Washington was also studied because it had a microbial community and sulfur content that was intermediate to Mahoney and Green Lake.

The geochemical and isotopic analysis of the water and sediments in these lakes created a robust database for comparing the process of organic sulfur compound formation under different environmental conditions. The analysis of sediment cores from these lakes also enabled us to look at sulfur reactions that occurred over thousand-year time scales. We also used cutting edge analytical approaches to characterize the distribution of dissolved organic matter in the lake water. Combined, this information enabled the development of a numerical approach to model the relative reaction rates. One central question focused on whether sulfur typically binds with iron to form pyrite or with organics. This competitive reaction can therefore place constraints on the amount of organic sulfur compounds that can form. In order to better constrain the microbial reactions that were likely responsible for the transformation of sulfur in these lakes, we also used genetic analysis to characterize the microbial community.

The broader impacts of this project include undergraduate and graduate education, postdoctoral training, and student outreach. One PhD student at IUPUI and another at the collaborating laboratory at the University of Pittsburgh focused their dissertation research on this project. Both PhD students received technical training in stable isotopic analysis and a variety of chemical extraction techniques. They received professional training through giving presentations at regional and national meetings. Two undergraduate students at IUPUI were supported on an REU supplement related to this project. Both students subsequently attended graduate school to earn MS degrees in earth sciences. One REU student project resulted in a first-authored scientific publication of a novel sulfur extraction method as part of this project. A postdoc at IUPUI received analytical training in organic geochemistry and professional training through presenting project outcomes at national and international meetings.

The outreach component included the development of educational modules using STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) principles to teach students about low oxygen conditions, known as hypoxia, in lakes and coastal oceans. Developed at IUPUI, the goal was to show middle school students the ways in which human activity such as the runoff of fertilizer into streams and rivers in the Midwest can ultimately contribute to hypoxia in large lakes and the ocean. Portions of the learning module were also used in an undergraduate oceanography course to demonstrate the hazards of human-induced hypoxia.
